comments.commentBody:
If you think of a reason not to off myself, please let me know.

I might be around at that time, but I cannot guarantee it.

Wow, I actually thought this was supposed to be a friendly exchange.

How bad have things gotten? I'm not sure I understand, but I do know my friend got it right about 14 years ago. I think we should all follow...
Nope.

"The results from the dog tests have been inconclusive..."

why? and the results surely depend on the dog, their training and the cancer. dogs are as different as people (who train them), and cancers are really not a single disease.

Both Salgado and Koudelka get A+++ on aesthetics; on journalism, Koudelka says nothing about the relation of the wall and the people it is meant to divide- only about how it relates to the land, as if the two can be separated. Salgado meanwhile, makes the most beautiful of landscapes funded by the very mining company that helps destroy them.

When I was in high school, I joined a rock and roll band. We organized our practices, set and met goals, scheduled engagements, set aside money from pay to purchase additional equipment including two Cadillac ambulances to haul our equipment to and from jobs. We also hired people to help us and all of this without an artificial test requirement. As you can imagine, just organizing five plus teenagers to make these commitments gave us a life long skill.

Learning and testing are two different things. Testing or assessments are a part of any learning endeavor but isn't always the singular goal. Most of my lifelong hobbies have never been about being tested. I have collected rocks, coins, and stamps; watched birds, painted trees, and continued to play music rarely with an outside assessment of my skills.

If a teacher sees a student one 50 minute period 180 days a year and then tests each of ten chapters, with one review day; sets aside four benchmark standard practice tests each taking two periods and a day or more review before each of them and then another week to the actual standardized grade level test...what percentage of the year will the students actually be learning lessons?

Then there is this truth, not everything you learn is revealed in the year you learned it. Think about the first time you heard your parents voice come out of your mouth when you were speaking to your kids. Some ideas mull around for 20 years before they make sense. Let teachers teach.
I've heard this time and time again.
As do prosecutors.

I have friends in both the D.A. and Public Defender offices. What's the only thing they agree on?

Cops lie.

Thank you, NYT, for covering this supremely flaws investigation so comprehensively. With the number of contradictions internally within the Florida police department, you all should be ashamed of yourselves.

SW,
I also picked up on that buried little nugget :Banks' age when he became a policeman. From having taught about 5K high school seniors, I shudder when I think of their being allowed to become cops while so young and uneducated. Florida is not unlike many states where the high school graduation line is drawn in the sand, and many graduates are dragged over. Unfortunately some of them are then given a gun and a badge.
We were given an idea--he lost his job and prized status as a cop.  He got that back after he flipped.

My guess is that both Banks and Shoar have something on O'Connell (no one is perfect), and threatened to make it public if he did not change his mind/story. Also, he was offered back his means to earn a living and support his family, which is no little incentive. But his conscience must be torturing him so bad...

Needed his job back to maintain his lifestyle? All other possible careers for which he is probably qualified are likely "salary challenged" and don't allow the ability to exercise the same level of power. Just a guess.
I wish we had been given some idea of why Scott O'Connell changed his mind and now says his sister committed suicide.

My brother was a police prosecutor and a relatively famous defense attorney.  He said if you wanted to commit a crime, hire a cop. In his opinion, cops were as crooked as any crooks.  Couple this situation with the militarization of police departments nationwide and we have a an incredible problem building in this country.

You've made a good case for not recruiting young people into the military where they are also wielding tremendous power and often lack self-control and judgment. Let's hope Kirsten Gillibrand's attempt to move military prosecution of sexual harassment and rape case responsibilities away from the chain of command is more successful than the thwarted attempts to find the truth in this Florida sheriff's jurisdiction.

Hmmmm....
Victims of officer involved domestic violence have never had a voice . DV agencies more often than not, will turn away OIDV victims - leaving these victims on their own with no help or resources.
This is the voice that has been silenced for too long. I do not understand why our roar makes you uncomfortable...

It has to be front page. Domestic violence is wide-spread throughout the world, and in many countries nobody would have bothered to talk about it, they would just have dug a hole in the backyard and stuffed the woman in there, alive (as happens in Turkey and other countries) or dead. Besides, this touches at the root of democracy. Law enforcement in democracy has to follow the word of the law and best practice, not the law of the mob.

I find the article to be an excellent piece of investigative journalism. This kind of reporting takes courage.

I do question whether it should be the lead story on the front page. Because the Times is the best paper in the world. And there is not even a close second. And traditionally, the article would have been further down the page, past the news about Kerry in Iran and other stories of national or international interest.

I also think the picture could have been visible as a link once the article was selected. The picture is not gratuitously framed or composed, but the placement of the picture next to the lead article is questionable.
I was also sickened by the way her brother suddenly decided the Sheriff was right after all -- and went back to work for the Sheriff.
What blew me away about this show, is that Glen managed to put himself in the shoes of OIDV victims everywhere. This is what OIDV victims are up against.

This was truly incredible journalism. After reading the article I also watched the PBS video others linked to: http://video.pbs.org/video/2365128108/ I appreciate the joint efforts and was able to see how extensive the reporting was. I applaud all involved.

I feel sick about this blatant miscarriage of justice. I cannot believe that the "boyfriend" was not tried for murder. But I am even more dumbfounded and downright sickened by the way the Sheriff and his minions acted. For the sheriff to so unequivocally proclaim he is right shows his absolutely myopic view. This is evidence to me as a citizen that he should not be in such a position of power. The fact that the boyfriend was never interrogated and was interviewed by his colleagues is also deeply troubling. How is that appropriate procedurally? It seems the Sheriff's office in St. Augustine has learned nothing from this case. I hope the attention as a result of the NYT and PBS reporting leads to justice for the family but also change in the way the St. Augustine police handle cases and police generally handle cases involving their own deputies. It's deeply sobering to see so cronyism and groupthink reign supreme.

To those who object to the photo of the victim's body, remember how Emmet Till's mother reacted to his death- she insisted that his mangled body be shown, that the brutality be remembered. Had she not felt that way, his name would not be associated with one of the worst (and all too common) crimes against blacks in the South.
Newspapers are for adults.  Tell your toddler it's a picture of a lady sleeping.  Make something up.  Don't penalize the actual readers of the Times.
Another theory is that during the concert, Jeremy somehow got hold of her cell phone and texted those messages himself - because he intended to kill her and make it look like a suicide.
I don't see it as circular logic. Why wouldn't she directly say in the emails that she's afraid of Jeremy, if she thought he might kill her?  Why break up with him on the drive home?
Renee--why would he kill her if not in a fit a rage?

From the article: “Although there was no suicide note, investigators believed that they had found the next best thing — cryptic text messages expressing concern about her daughter, Alexis, that Ms. O’Connell had sent while attending a rock concert that evening with Mr. Banks and her brother Sean... To investigators, the texts signaled a despondent young woman on the verge of suicide.”

In a neat display of circular logic, the investigators found that Michelle’s text messages expressed suicidal thoughts because it dovetailed nicely with their (only) working hypothesis. I have another theory: that Michelle was foreseeing her own death, or at least the very real possibility of it, that night, and not by suicide. Banks was already “pissed off” at the concert — so much so that her brother switched seats with him — and she was clearly afraid of him and knew he wasn’t going to let her just leave exit the relationship. It’s not much of a stretch that her overriding concern at the concert would be her four-year-old daughter and what would happen to her in the event of her death.

How agonizing it must have been for her. And now these “investigators” have managed to turn this maternal concern into evidence of suicidal thinking. What do they make of the arguing and screaming coming from Banks’s house, and the cries for help? Part of her pre-suicide ritual, no doubt. What exactly are their credentials as investigators anyway? And why isn’t the Justice Department looking into this case?

Bravo. Well stated and true. And in many cases, the parents leave the teachers with the task of maintaining that education should be the priority over social life or sports prowess. My students' biggest complaint about writing papers or reading is "I don't have time." Yes, in some ways the world is more complicated. Parents, however, are making the education of their children more complicated by not establishing the wonder of learning nor the study habits necessary to gain the education.

For the initial article, by the way, I would score quite low due to logical fallacies. Yikes.

My understanding of kids was all abstract and theoretical before I had one.  While I think you raise valid and important questions, I don't think you understand what a complicated world they are growing up in, quite different from the one I grew up in 35 years ago.  Parents now invest a lot of energy and attention in their children, and see them more than ever as a reflection of those efforts.   When I was a teenager in the 70s, I had an amazing amount of freedom and there were times I was completely off my parents' radar.  I can't give that level of freedom to my own daughter-- the world is very different.  Just a few examples--there is nonstop social media.  Whether or not your kid participates, it has a major effect on them and their relationships every day, and so much of everything is hyper-public .  Most boys start seeing hard core porn by middle school. 2 or 3 years later they're my daughter's dates.  There are drugs like K2, a marijuana knock-off that's sold legally as incense and can cause complete mania.  On the other end of the spectrum, sports start to get intensely serious by middle school, and can have kids getting up at 5 am for practice and being driven for night games that get them home at 10.  What always gets forgotten or unaddressed in the discussions about how coddled kids are are all the other very real everyday aspects of their' lives that have accelerated and intensified, and which affect them at least as much as the quality of their education.

The first time I saw someone bleeding to death from a gunshot wound on a sidewalk, I was seven years old.

I know how many different worlds exist inside America, having lived in a few of them, but it still sometimes takes me by surprise. I just find myself thrown, a bit, realizing that my country has people who feel entitled to demand that they never see gun violence, even in a photo.

Not saying you are wrong - I've done everything I can to get away from having to see that kind of thing too - just that it's strange how differently we all live.

Agree.

I often say ". . . give them a gun and a badge . . ." and they think they are god and can do anything anytime to anybody and nothing ever happens to them.

./

Until the time comes when the "good police officers" decide to rid their midst of the sociopaths, nothing will change. The "good police officers" share in the culpability through silence or inaction.

The police are losing the trust of the citizenry they're sworn to protect and serve. They've adopted an "us against them" mentality, which will become a sefl-fullfilling situation in the near future.

Judges, prosecutors and the defense bar know the realities, but nobody wants to do anything about it, for they believe that the system will collapse if those realities are officially acknowledged. It is left to journalists to shine a light on the present dark practices.

I really do not trust police, too much power with no accountability. They act like bullies in high school with their varsity jackets. It is very sad that all the good police officers are tainted by the few sociopaths in their midst, but it's in their interests to weed them out.

David Koch, Mr. potato head, look behind you...

You're gone...

Gotcha!!!

"The best way to get good results from kids is to have a great teacher."

The other two legs of the stool supporting any child's accomplishments are of course the parents.
Confidence without the ability to perform is arrogance. Bullies are confident until someone stands up to them and teaches them that everything has its price.

Mr. Bruni,

There is a difference between wanting every kid to feel brilliant and wanting every kid to be confident. Maybe parents are so obsessed with tending their children's egos because they have seen how the real world works, and it is not necessarily the smartest or most capable who succeed. It is the people who are confidence, who don't get discouraged by their failures, and are highly motivated. What I see in parents who are highly involved with their kids is their interest in finding something that sparks their kids passion.

I don't understand why school can't be some combination of memorizing and analytic ability.

Also, an ambitious agenda in the hands of a mediocre teacher is not helpful. The best way to get good results from kids is to have a great teacher. Kids know when they have a teacher who knows how to do the job, and they appreciate it. My daughter had a teacher in high school who still didn't know the kids names by the time of the first progress report. Do you think she was going to work hard for that teacher?

How judgmental we can be, Merrill. Christians are not perfect but say that they have found a way to be better. Which is worse: to be bad and know it and want to change, or to accept how one is inside and just accept that?
Every Christian I have met, and all the non-believers I have met, continued to be fallible human beings after I met them.

You are absolutely right; the highest use of journalism. An incredible job by the NY Times. One wonders how many other cases wind up like this. It is very sobering to realize the caliber of people that are involved in "protecting" the public. The sheriff is clearly an inept, self-promoting boob who hides behind the circus of religion and is a mini-tyrant in his own jurisdiction. Mr. Banks, I am sure, will be in trouble with the law again. Anger like that doesn't go away. The most shocking part of this story is the police ineptitude, the obvious fact that they did not do their job right from the start, and then the more shocking progression of the story to the "obvious" conclusion that Ms. O'Connell committed suicide. They piled one ineptitude on another, one lie on another, and the train just kept chugging along until we reach the bizarre last scene where this sheriff is asking Mr. Banks to stand up and be applauded as a great American citizen!? Along with the victim's brother! That is bone chilling. The lesson I learned from this, which I sort of always knew to be true is "stay away from the police". The last thing they want in your life if justice." Unlike on Law and Order where they mock a person for getting a lawyer, the first thing you should do is "lawyer up". It's your best protection because the people in charge are scarier than the criminals they pursue.
Bravo to the Times.

Steve, I don't think Merrill is  referring to all Christians generally, only to "his type" which she has seen from her experience. I suspect she has in mind his hypocrisy, and indeed I don't find any evidence in the story that the sheriff knows he is bad and wants to change, as you put it. He seems fairly self-satisfied.

Great article. Thanks to the New York Times and all the people who worked on this.

It's a little off-topic, but I recently attended a showing of "Gideon's Army," an HBO documentary about public defenders and how hard they have to fight with no resources for their clients (a movie everyone should see, by the way) . A panel of public defenders was there to talk about the movie afterwards. Someone asked what they had learned from their work.

"There is no justice," one of them answered.

I hope this article brings some justice to this case. The highest use of journalism.

And I'm not surprised this sheriff calls himself a Christian. Having grown up in the South, I've seen his type all my life, and I'm sick of them.

Kennedy's goals were sabotaged by Republican obstruction in Congress. He tried and failed to pass a civil rights bill, to keep bankers and industrialists under control, and to restrain CIA and Pentagon warmongers.

Johnson ultimately had success with some of Kennedy's dreams, when more of us belatedly realized that justice and peace were American concepts. Even Johnson couldn't restrain the warmongers, leading us to Vietnam and a long night of military hubris and waste.

My father, an Army colonel, was inspired by Kennedy, and so were his children. Dad saw the freaks in the Pentagon up close, and it worried him enough to request early retirement.

I'm tired of right wing historical revisionists pointing to Congressional stalemate during Kennedy's tenure. They need to point the finger at themselves instead, a situation being reenacted today, with even worse results.

John Kennedy was funny, brave, brilliant, and determined to rein in the dark forces he saw in Washington. Those of us who lived through those three years, even as kids, will never forget him.
In case you're wondering, it is Mr. Potato Head, David Koch that has invaded the conversations above.  Have fun weeding his influence out of your organization.

The "C" question is a good one and there's no "right" answer. In general, clues that contain part of the answer are avoided, but not always. Sometimes the rule is suspended because that's the point of the clue. For instance, today we have, "The 'S' of R.S.V.P. " (SIL). I suspect that didn't bother you because mixing S (twice!) and SIL is pretty clearly intended, and we're on the lookout for errors, right?

The reason for the rule is spoiler prevention. Cluing AEC or NRC as "Watchdog commission" would be a pretty big spoiler. But cluing one with the other not so much. I didn't find myself even thinking the word "commission" when I went from clue to entry. They're just associated three-letter initialisms and the fact that they share a word when spelled out didn't make the clue any easier for me.

I can't say for sure, but my observation is that Will tends to look at this "rule," and others, this way. He's more concerned with the spirit of the rule than its letter.

I didn't find the "handle" clue a stretch, just clever. One of the best in the puzzle actually.

I still wonder about SWEET CAROLINE fitting into the theme when the actual reference in the song is to Ms. Kennedy.

Thank you all!!! See, there is always something to learn here at Wordplay. Something I might want to know, in contrast to what I learned today about MBNYJ.

NW Corner, I don't know if you are tall and dapper, but you may have a future in the XWP-blogging business.

Martin, I very much appreciate your explanation and especially your providing of context. I tend to think that if arrows were printable in the clues, the S'IL clue would have shown RSVP with an arrow pointing to the S; but since there's no arrow, the clue has to "point" us to the second part of Repondez s'il vous plai t by other means. Using the S in the clue is the chosen means. It was more the dual C's (which each time "represent" "Commission" both in actuality and in my brain) that made me raise the question.

Deb, your Reply was very much appreciated and highly readable so I could check off the parts of my long-form stupid question as I went through your explanations.

However, I cannot in any circumstances condone your taking action that makes a grown Timesman* cry!

* -- officially sanctioned word for a male Times employee, see, e.g. perhaps maybe http://publiceditor.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/11/22/a-50-year-timesman-reca... ? **

** -- I'm no public editor and I'm FAR from being a Robert C. Semple, Jr. THIS reply will probably be filtered out if I refer to "the most exciting moment I've had", as they did in the cited blog post. Let's find out.

So, what follows is about entries, cluing, and the fact that I am apparently more-easily addled than the irrepressible Soupy trying to figure out what to do with a thrown object.

Separate question/comment seeking answers/explanations/guidance from Deb or anyone:

I had a couple of problems with 44A's entry.

1. It is among an unusual number of words appearing today (clues or grid) that I can't use in comments.

2. 44A is not exactly far from 29A, yet the entry for the first forms the center of the entry for the second. Is that Halal?

I had a couple of problems with 29A.

1. See "2" above.

2. Try as I might, I have not divined the slightest connection, clever or otherwise, between clue and entry.

I wondered about 88A and 90A:

I have learned from this blog and comments that it is a no-no to write a clue that contains an element of the answer. So why does the C in NRC and AEC not make the one a TABU clue for the other? Separately, why does the word "too" not require tweaking of a clue for ET TU?

And guys, that's "tweaking", OK? T-W-E-A. A.

Thanks!

-- Might iT Feel-good-to-get-answers?
